Greg Walden and three congressional colleagues — all fellow Republicans— on Thursday requested a federal investigation of Oregon's troubled health insurance exchange, which has been unable to sign up a single person through its online portal because of technical problems that were known months before it was supposed to launch.

docs.lead_paragraph: While states are having varying success getting people to sign up, January marked the first time since new health insurance markets opened last fall that a national monthly enrollment target was met.

headline.main: January Insurance Sign-Ups Meet Monthly Goal
headline.print_headline: January Insurance Sign-Ups Meet Monthly Goal

docs.lead_paragraph: More than 1.1 million people signed up for health insurance through federal and state marketplaces in January, according to the government.

headline.main: Over 1 Million Added to Rolls of Health Plan
headline.print_headline: Over 1 Million Added to Rolls of Health Plan

docs.abstract: Department of Health and Human Services reports that more than 1.1 million people signed up for health insurance through federal and state marketplaces in Jan 2014, as key youth demographic enrolled at faster rate than any other group; brings total to 3.3 million in first four months of enrollment; results are hailed by Obama administration, but are unlikely to tamp down political fight over the Affordable Care Act in lead-up to midterm elections.

docs.lead_paragraph: Litigation and regulation are better than legislative bans.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by law student Jacob M Victor holds that existing state laws forbidding businesses from engaging in deceptive practices may be more effective at ending gay conversion therapy than state laws that ban such practices outright; says businesses' claims that sexual orientation can be changed falls under umbrella of deceptive trade practice.
docs.snippet: Litigation and regulation are better than legislative bans.

docs.lead_paragraph: About one-fourth of the total are the young adults so avidly sought by insurers because they are usually healthier and need fewer medical services.
